" "Of course when you find a toe above the ground
column6: you want to know where the toe came from. When you examine it
column7: you see a name written on there. This toe belongs to the local clumsy farmhand
column8: Jourm (じょう).

column1: - Hint: Try to remember Jourm
column2: the local farmhand. He is a recurring character that will come up anytime the reading for a kanji is じょう.

column1: - Hint: He is a very big man
column2: and he wears farmer's clothes. It's important to imagine your version of Jourm as very big
column3: because it will help us to differentiate him from Jo-Anne
column4: who is the character associated with the similar
column5: but shorter reading (and character) <jp>じょ</jp>. Although Jourm will develop as you go through all the <jp>じょう</jp> reading kanji
column6: for now just imagine him as a big
column7: kinda slow dude who works for a local farmer. Also
column8: he only has nine or fewer toes

" "You keep digging for the toe below the ground
column7: and instead of hitting a <radical>toe</radical> you hit something hard and metallic. You keep digging and digging around it
column8: but it's huge. Turns out
column9: you found yourself a <reading>car</reading> (<jp>か</jp>). Keep digging until you unearth the car. Inside
column10: you find the toe you were looking for.

column1: - Hint: There's another useful on'yomi reading that just isn't useful enough for you to learn now. That reading is <jp>げ</jp>
column2: but we're only going to worry about that much
column3: much later when you have to learn one or two vocab words that read <jp>下</jp> as <jp>げ</jp>. That's the problem with really common kanji - too many readings."	Kanji Reading	-	Kanji_Reading Level_1

" "For kanji that use the こう (there are a lot of them!) we will use the character こういち every time. He's one of the people who started this website
column4: so we'll do our best in the mnemonics to embarrass him as much as possible. Anyways
column5: remember that whenever you see <jp>こう</jp>
column6: think こういち.

column1: You see some <kanji>construction</kanji> in front of you. There
column2: standing shirtless (only a suspender and hard hat) is (<reading><jp>こう</jp></reading>)
column3: looking back at you.

column1: - Hint: If <jp>こういち</jp> as a construction worker standing in a construction site some how doesn't make your legs tremble
column2: that's okay and totally normal. Do make sure you take this story to a ridiculous enough level to hook a memory into that brain of yours. Be mad at him for not following construction site regulations (where's his shirt
column3: shoes
column4: and pants!?). Why is he using that bulldozer like that?

column1: - Hint: Alternatively
column2: say you really do like what you see (you're going to have to imagine a much better looking version of <jp>こういち</jp>'s actual face
column3: though). You and <jp>こういち</jp> make eye contact a little too long. He nods
column4: puts his cigarette out
column5: and takes off his hard hat
column6: letting his long Fabio-esque locks flow. You beckon him over and he comes. What happens next is up to you and your own imagination. My guess is you have a very deep conversation about kanji and the best ways to learn it.

column1: - Hint: Hint: When you see <jp>工</jp> in a kanji it will often take the <jp>こう</jp> reading. Remember that
column2: because it comes up quite a bit!"	Kanji Reading	-	Kanji_Reading Level_1

column1: For kanji with <jp>こう</jp> readings (there are a lot of them!) we will use the character <jp>こういち</jp> every time. He's one of the people who started this website
column2: so we'll do our best in the mnemonics to embarrass him as much as possible. Anyways
column3: remember that whenever you see <jp>こう</jp>

column1: - Hint: You just can't forget all the cool things about kanji learning he said from that mouth. What a great mouth <jp>こういち</jp> has. How are the lips of his mouth both so skinny and fat at the same time?"	Kanji Reading	-	Kanji_Reading Level_1

" "Although this kanji has two on'yomi to learn

column5: so that should make them easier to remember.

column1: When you were nine your favorite foods were cookies (く) and cucumbers (きゅう). Yum yum!
- Hint: Picture nine-year-old you
column2: lining up nine cookies and nine cucumbers. You dip a cookie in milk and bite into it
column3: then dip a cucumber in and take a bite. Nine bites each until they're all gone. Ah
column4: you miss being nine."	Kanji Reading	-	Kanji_Reading Level_1

" "As you're sitting there next to One
column4: holding him up
column5: you start feeling a weird sensation all over your skin. From the wound comes a fine powder (obviously coming from the special bullet used to kill One) that causes the person it touches to get extremely itchy (いち).

column1: - Hint: Make sure you feel the ridiculously <reading>itchy</reading> sensation covering your body. It climbs from your hands
column2: where you're holding the number <kanji>One</kanji> up
column3: and then goes through your arms
column4: crawls up your neck
column5: goes down your body
column6: and then covers everything. It becomes uncontrollable
column7: and you're scratching everywhere
column8: writhing on the ground. It's so itchy that it's the most painful thing you've ever experienced (you should imagine this vividly
column9: so you remember the reading of this kanji)."	Kanji Reading	-	Kanji_Reading Level_1

" "To remember the sounds し and す we'll use these mnemonics:

column1: There is a <kanji>child</kanji> standing in front of you. You look closely at the child but something seems wrong. You rub your eyes and when you open them again there is a <reading>shee</reading>p (<jp>し</jp>) in a <reading>su</reading>it (<jp>す</jp>) in front of you. You yelp
column2: blink
column3: and it's back to being a child. Are... all children really just sheep in suits?!

column1: - Hint: The child runs away and you chase after it. Every time it's about to turn a corner it looks like a sheep in a suit again
column2: but whenever you yell and point
column3: it turns back. You're the only one who can see this sheep suit child!!"	Kanji Reading	-	Kanji_Reading Level_2
